Award.AwardTitle: EARS: GOALI: Low-Power, Multi-Tiered, Shared-Spectrum Access Terminals using Compressive Scanning and On-Top-of-CMOS BAW Filter Banks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cognitive mobile devices that sense and exploit available spectral resources have the potential for very broad societal impact, from business and government to the education and non-profit sectors.The proposed research leverages the interdisciplinary nature of the team and the industry-academic partnership towards realizing the cognitive radio vision to enhance access to the radio spectrum. The industrial partnership will specifically provide the essential system and application context to facilitate faster translation of the research into practice. Three graduate students will be trained in this highly cross-disciplinary area. The PIs will further develop Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) projects as part of the program to expand undergraduate participation.

As wireless systems continue to proliferate and the demand for instantaneous, over-the-air access to large volumes of content continues to grow, radio spectrum (especially in the 500MHz-6GHz range) is an increasingly scarce resource. Most of the useful spectrum has been licensed. A few license-free bands are crowded to capacity, while many licensed bands are underutilized. Cognitive radios propose to scan and opportunistically share spectrum. They have the potential for expanding the available spectrum through opportunistic use, if conflict can be sensed and avoided by continuously monitoring higher priority traffic. This requires agile, low-power solutions for spectrum scanning and bandwidth aggregation receivers. This project studies these challenges in the context of a multi-tiered shared-spectrum access communication system. It focuses on tier-3 cognitive radio terminals that scan and dynamically use radio spectrum that is underutilized by higher tier users. It proposes novel bandpass compressed spectrum scanner architectures and recovery algorithms, that promise to substantially reduce power consumption and scan time compared to existing solutions. To enable interference-robust, reconfigurable receiver architectures with noncontiguous bandwidth aggregation, reconfigurable arrays of bulk acoustic wave devices fabricated on top of CMOS will be investigated. The industrial partnership is key to provide system and application knowledge, as well as system integration expertise to test and evaluate the innovations. The cross-disciplinary research questions are important for broadband RF systems in general, and the proposed solutions will have impact beyond multi-tiered cognitive radio systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader Impact

Wireless communication is a pervasive technology and growth enabler in modern societies. In first-world economies, wireless connectivity is essential to the functioning of business, government, educational, entertainment, and non-profit sectors. In developing countries, wireless technologies are playing an even more crucial role for economic development, development of infrastructure, fighting poverty, and managing disease. They enable mobile payments, distribution of crop treatment schedules, dissemination of current market prices, and the tracking and prevention of disease spread.

The spectacular growth in wireless use has already led to a significant spectrum scarcity. Soon billions of new devices ranging from personal health monitoring devices to smart cars and unmanned aerial vehicles will compete with mobile phones for access to an increasingly congested electromagnetic spectrum. The current paradigm of pre-allocating spectrum for use by designated classes of devices will no longer be sufficient to guarantee access to all.

Cognitive Radio (CR) will be an essential technology to overcome this roadblock for further growth. Future CR terminals will rapidly gain awareness of their fast-changing spectrum environment and opportunistically access a shared pool of spectrum. While different functions needed in future CR terminals have been demonstrated on-chip, these are currently implemented in distinct hardware blocks. One key outcome of this effort has been the development of functionally flexible and rapidly reconfigurable architectures compactly implemented on silicon that can achieve the cost, size and power targets in mass-market applications. By enabling the more efficient use of spectral resources through Cognitive Radio technologies, the findings of this effort have the potential to reduce the need for capital-intensive investments in new infrastructure and allow further expansion of wireless systems.

This grant provided critical resources for support and training for graduate research students both at the master’s and doctoral level. The GOALI extension for this grant enabled an industrial partnership that has provided the essential system and application context to facilitate faster translation of the research into practice. A Research-Experience-for-Teachers extension made the training about RF experiments possible for a high-school science research teacher to be applied in student research projects studying the properties of RF waves and the RF properties of materials. The Research-Experience-for-Undergraduates extension offered undergraduate students the essential experience of being part of a larger research project during their studies.  Several of the undergraduate students involved in REU activities related to the project are now enrolled in PhD-track graduate programs and were supported by their interactions with the research.

Intellectual Merit

This interdisciplinary research project offers novel, key solutions for Cognitive Radio multi-tiered shared spectrum access terminals. This includes compressed-sampling (CS) spectrum scanners, bandwidth aggregating RF receivers with on-top-of-CMOS LOBAR filter arrays. The evolution of the CS spectrum scanner technology developed during this research effort is illustrated in Fig. 1. The quadrature analog-to-information converter (QAIC) is a very energy-efficient, bandpass CS spectrum-scanner architecture. The time-segmented quadrature analog-to-information converter (TS-QAIC) retained the benefits of the QAIC and introduces the ability to deal with rapidly changing spectrum environments. The direct RF-to-information converter (DRF2IC) further improved the energy-efficiency of the QAIC by an order of magnitude and unified CS spectrum sensing with high-sensitivity signal reception into a single reconfigurable architecture.

The versatility of the DRF2IC architecture is illustrated in Fig. 2. The DRF2IC can be configured to function as a sweeping spectrum analyzer, a CS spectrum scanner, and a high-sensitivity signal receiver. Even though the DRF2IC is a reconfigurable architecture its performance in as a sweeping spectrum analyzer compares favorably to recently published single-function integrated analyzers; in addition, as a CS spectrum scanner, the DRF2IC delivers the best-reported speed and energy consumption when compared to recently published CS scanners.

The industrial partnership for this grant was key in providing system and application knowledge, as well as system integration expertise, to develop a testbed (see Fig. 3) for evaluation of the cross-disciplinary technology innovations.

The cross-layer questions that were studied in this project are important for broadband RF systems in general, and we expect our answers to these questions to have impact beyond multi-tiered cognitive radio systems. Signal reconstruction problems arising in cognitive radio the development of new systems-level approaches to adaptively handling time-varying spectral occupancies, which should be impactful in analog-to-information conversion in dynamic or complex environments. Nonlinearities and nonidealities motivate the development of new nonlinear signal reconstruction strategies based on nonconvex optimization. These strategies leverage recently discovered geometric phenomena in high-dimensional nonconvex optimization, which imply that simple local methods efficiently obtain globally optimal solutions, with implications for a wide range of signal reconstruction problems.

Several advancements in the fabrication technology of on-chip resonators were also developed.  In particular, several of the challenges specific to the adaptation of the system to scaled technologies with low-K and small-scale CMP back-ends with fill patterns were addressed in the program.
